newsitem.title: GERMANY: Daimler puts off restructuring decision until 1997.
newsitem.headline: Daimler puts off restructuring decision until 1997.

text.p: German industrial giant Daimler-Benz AG, whose reorganisation plans have sparked an internal power struggle, on Tuesday said it would put off a decision about a corporate overhaul until early 1997.
"The board wants to consider the management structure more intensively over the next few weeks," it said in a statement after a meeting of the executive committee of its supervisory board.

Germany's largest industrial group has been considering a reorganisation for some months, as part of efforts to make individual operating units more profitable, and closer integration of its main car and truck making operation, Mercedes-Benz.
What would become of Mercedes and its chairman, Helmut Werner, has become the object of intense internal political manoeuvring.

The reorganisation has led to bad blood within the Daimler group, where speculation of a turf war between Mercedes-Benz chairman Werner and Daimler group chairman Juergen Schrempp has grown almost by the day.
According to local media, Werner has threatened to resign if his operation were integrated more closely.

Industry sources on Monday said Schrempp, desperate to prevent the loss of the highly-regarded Werner, has gone as far as to offer the Mercedes boss a top job in the restructured Daimler in order to keep him on board.
Werner's contract as management board member of Daimler, which expires at the end of 1997, is up for renewal at a supervisory board meeting on November 6. His contract at Mercedes runs until 1999.
But Daimler said on Tuesday that it would not decide any personnel moves at the November meeting.

Mercedes officials, who oversee the bulk of Daimler's profit and revenues, have reportedly baulked at closer integration and are resentful that their operation must help underwrite loss-making units such as Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG.
Mercedes, which now makes up around three-quarters of Daimler's group revenues, has predicted its 1996 profits will be clearly higher than last year's 2.275 billion marks ($1.49 billion).
According to company sources, six of seven board members at Daimler favour plans to integrate Mercedes into the parent with only Werner opposed to the move.
Despite the support of board members, analysts said Schrempp was in no position to force his wishes through.
Daimler has already suffered a series of public relations fiascos recently, including a record 5.3 billion mark loss last year.
